big_picture_notes: Genesis presents the origin narrative in two arcs: Primordial Dawn (creation through Babel) establishes the cosmic backdrop and universal human need for redemption, while Patriarchal Promise traces God's covenant with Abraham and his descendants, establishing the foundation for all subsequent biblical history. The narrative moves from universal to particular as God narrows His redemptive focus through a 'narrative funnel' that diagnoses universal problems and zooms into particular solutions.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with 'Bereshit' establishing cosmic scope; ends with Day 7 blessing and sanctification via inclusio. Unified by strict formulaic repetition, topical parallelism (Days 1-3 form realms; Days 4-6 fill them), and numerology (7 days, 7 'good' statements, 35 God references). Functions as liturgical creation hymn.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 1:1 summary. Ends with ruach Elohim hovering. Devices: Merism ('heavens/earth'=cosmos); Alliteration (Bereshit bara' 'Elohim).
Starts with first fiat; ends with first temporal marker. Devices: Core pattern (command, fulfillment, evaluation, separation, naming, time).
Starts with raqiya command; ends with 'second day.' Devices: Separation (waters above/below); only day not 'good.'
Starts with gather waters command; ends with naming and 'good.' Devices: Separation/gathering act.
Starts with vegetation command; ends with 'third day.' Devices: Repetition 'according to kinds'; second 'good' completes Forming triad.
Starts with 'fill expanse' command; ends with 'fourth day.' Devices: Parallels Day 1; describes function (ANE sun/moon polemic); chiastic.
Starts with 'fill waters/sky' command; ends with 'fifth day.' Devices: Parallels Day 2; first bara since 1:1; first blessing 'be fruitful.'
Starts with 'fill land' command; ends with 'sixth day.' Climax. Devices: Parallels Day 3; divine consultation ('Let us'); 'image of God' repetition; 'very good' escalation.
Starts with completion summary; ends with Day 7 sanctification. Devices: Inclusio (reverses 1:1 terms); hallows time as creation pinnacle; establishes Sabbath covenant.

stories.story_title: The Eden Narrative and the Human Fall
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Starts with toledot hinge; ends with irreversible expulsion. Diptych with Story 1 (Order→Chaos). Pervasive wordplay: 'adam/'adamah, 'ishah/'ish, 'arûm/'arûmmîm, Hawwah/hay. Theme of boundaries (violation of single God-set boundary). Chapters 2-3 inseparable.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with toledot. Ends with man formed. Devices: Narrative zoom-in Day 6; wordplay 'adam/'adamah; anthropomorphism.
Starts with garden planting; ends with prohibition and consequence (death). Devices: Symbolism (trees represent choice); etiology (four rivers).
Starts with 'not good to be alone.' Ends with no suitable helper found. Devices: Narrative suspense; man's dominion (naming); 'ezer implies equality.
Starts with deep sleep solution; ends with innocence ('naked, not ashamed'). Devices: Anthropomorphism (surgeon/attendant); wordplay 'ishah/'ish; 'one flesh' etiology.
Starts with serpent; ends with denial ('You will not die'). Devices: Wordplay 'arûm/'arûmmîm; three-step tactic: doubt, distort, deny.
Starts with woman's deliberation; ends with eyes opened. Devices: Woman's evaluation parallels God's; irony (know good/evil but not godhood); Adam's passive complicity.
Starts with God walking; ends with blame-shifting. Devices: Anthropomorphism; rhetorical questions provoke confession; relationship breakdown revealed.
Starts with serpent judgment; ends with man's mortality. Devices: Triad of speeches in reverse sin order; only serpent/ground 'cursed'; consequences in created purpose spheres.
Starts with Adam naming wife; ends with garment provision. Devices: Profound irony (immediately after death, names 'Eve'=mother of living); first animal death foreshadows sacrifice.
Starts with God's monologue; ends with cherubim posting. Devices: Sarcasm/irony (mortal despite knowledge); expulsion seals garden; etiology (mortality, separation).

stories.story_title: Cain and Abel: The Spread of Sin
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Starts with first human birth, logical sequel to expulsion. Ends with Seth's birth and calling on LORD, contrasting 'way of Cain' with godly Seth line. Structural parallelism to Fall (Sin→Confrontation→Curse→Exile). Repetition of 'brother' (7x) and 'Cain' (14x) hammer horror. Wordplay: Qayin/qanah, Havel/vanity, Nod/wanderer.

scenes.scene_name: The Two Brothers and Their Offerings
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with births and occupations. Ends with offering rejection and fallen face. Devices: Wordplay on names; sparse text creates tension; later texts attribute to lack of faith.
Starts with dialogue ('Why angry?'). Ends with famous warning ('sin crouches at door'). Devices: Personification (sin as rōbēṣ predator); repetition of 'face.'
Starts with brothers in field. Ends with murder in single stark verse. Devices: Sparsity makes violence shocking; repetition 'his brother' emphasizes fratricide.
Starts with 'Where is Abel?' Ends with exile to Nod. Devices: Parallel to 3:9; dramatic irony ('Am I keeper?'=yes); Abel's blood cries; wordplay adamah→Nod; mark shows grace.
Starts with Enoch. Ends with Lamech's 'Song of Sword.' Devices: Charts civilization (cities, music, metalwork) and sin progress; climaxes in Lamech; dark parallelism.

scenes.scene_name: The Birth of Seth and Hope
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Adam's new son. Ends with 'began calling on LORD.' Devices: Wordplay Shet/appointed; hopeful inclusio contrasting Lamech with faithful calling; establishes godly line.

stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with toledot formula, formally separating from genealogy. Ends with patriarchal death formula, closing definitively. Massive chiasm pivoting on 'God remembered Noah' (8:1); flood rising (Gen 7) mirrored by receding (Gen 8). Un-creation/re-creation theme: fountains/windows reverse Day 2; water-covered mountains reverse Day 3; ruach mirrors 1:2; 'be fruitful' repeats Genesis 1 blessing.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with toledot. Ends with diagnosis: 'all flesh corrupted.' Devices: Character contrast (Noah righteous/walked with God vs. Earth corrupt/violent); repetition.

scenes.scene_name: First Speech: Judgment and Build Command
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'I have decided...' Ends with Noah's perfect obedience. Devices: Divine monologue with ark specs; ark as microcosm/new creation vessel.
Starts with second enter command. Ends with Noah's obedience. Devices: Parallel repetitive command; introduces clean/unclean distinction for 8:20 sacrifice.
Starts with Noah's age and family entering. Ends with 'LORD shut him in.' Devices: Narrates commanded entry; God's action symbolizes both salvation and judgment.
Starts with flood beginning. Ends with waters prevailing 150 days. Devices: Hyperbole; repetition/intensification 'prevailed' (military assault feel); un-creation to chaos.
Starts with narrative pivot 'God remembered Noah.' Ends with ark rests, mountaintops visible. Devices: Literary/theological center; 'remembered' means 'acted on behalf'; ruach allusion to 1:2.

Starts with window opening after 40 days. Ends with dove not returning, signifying dry land. Devices: Narrative pacing (7-day waits build suspense); symbolism (unclean vs. clean); olive leaf metaphor.
Starts with exact date (601st year). Ends with confirmation of dryness. Devices: Precise chronological data gives narrative 'facticity.'
Starts with disembark command. Ends with all creatures leaving. Devices: Parallels boarding scenes, fulfilling chiasm; implicit 'be fruitful' command.
Starts with altar building. Ends with 'never curse ground again.' Devices: Etiology of post-flood sacrifice; story's theological climax; grace despite knowing 'human heart evil from childhood.'
Starts with formal blessing. Ends with repeated 'be fruitful' command. Devices: Allusion to Genesis 1:28; re-creation with modifications: 'fear/dread' replaces harmony; meat diet reflects post-Fall.
Starts with covenant speech. Ends with rainbow sign summary. Devices: Repetition of 'covenant'; covenant is unilateral and universal; rainbow as war bow showing cessation of hostilities.

scenes.scene_name: Epilogue: Noah's Drunkenness and Canaan's Curse
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Noah's sons identification. Ends with Noah's death, closing toledot. Devices: Tragic epilogue; parallelism (man of soil plants vineyard, fall with fruit/nakedness mirrors Adam); etiology for Canaan subjugation.

stories.story_title: The Tower of Babel: Humanity's Hubris
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Starts with 'whole earth had one language' (unity setup). Ends with etiological summary and scattering. Tight concentric chiasm: human plan ('Come, let us') mirrored by divine plan; human goal ('prevent scatter') mirrored by divine action ('scattered'); God's descent is center. Irony: tower to reach heaven too small for LORD to see. Wordplay: Babel/balal (confuse); nilbĕnâ/nāblâ; shem presages genealogy.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with unified setting. Ends with rebellious plan: build city/tower for 'name' (self-exaltation) and prevent dispersal (disobedience to Gen 1 & 9). Devices: Repetition 'Come, let us.'

Starts with God's descent (chiastic pivot). Ends with divine consultation ironically mirroring human plan. Devices: Irony (must come down to see); repetition 'one people...language' frames unity as threat.
Starts with 'LORD scattered them.' Ends with Babel wordplay conclusion. Devices: Irony (greatest fear v.4 becomes punishment v.8); etiology (origin of Babel/languages).

stories.story_title: The Abraham Cycle: The Promise and Its Trials
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with toledot of Terah (11:27) introducing first obstacle: barrenness (11:30). Ends after death (25:8); v.25:11 passes torch to Isaac. All plot points resolved: son born (21) and tested (22); land secured (23); lineage continued (24). Promise vs. Obstacle structure: son→barrenness/age/Hagar/Akedah; land→famine/Lot-conflict. Wife-sister motif twice (12, 20) shows promise preserved by God, not Abram. Large chiasm: A: Call (12:1-3)→A': Test (22:1-19); B: Egypt (12)→B': Gerar (20); C: Lot (13)→C': Sodom (18-19); Center: Covenant (17).

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with toledot. Ends with family in Haran, key obstacle: 'Sarai was barren.' Devices: Sets central tension for cycle.
Starts with 'Leave your country...' Ends with obedience and altar in Canaan. Inciting incident. Devices: Divine speech; threefold promise (Land/Nation/Blessing) is theological engine.
Starts with famine threat. Ends with expulsion, wife restored. Devices: First wife-sister motif showing Abraham's fear; God's intervention (plagues) protects promise, not Abram.
Starts with land conflict. Ends with separation and promise reaffirmation. Devices: Character contrast (Abram generous; Lot chooses doomed plain).
Starts with plain invasion. Ends with Abram refusing spoils after Melchizedek blessing. Devices: Introduces mysterious priest-king; Abram as military hero rescuing Lot.

Starts with reassurance ('I am your shield...'). Ends with formal covenant ceremony. Devices: Abram's doubt ('childless'); God's unilateral covenant (smoking firepot passing through pieces) binds Himself.
Starts with Sarai's Hagar plan. Ends with Ishmael's birth. Devices: Human attempt to 'solve' promise creates conflict.
Starts with El Shaddai appearance. Ends with obedience (circumcision). Devices: Covenant sign given; names changed (Abram→Abraham; Sarai→Sarah); Isaac explicitly promised.
Starts with visitors at Mamre. Ends with Sarah's laughter. Devices: Anthropomorphism (God in human form, eats); Sarah's laughter (Isaac=laughs) symbolizes doubt→joy.
Starts with God's internal monologue. Ends with intercession ceasing at ten righteous. Devices: Dialogue as negotiation; Abraham developing as intercessor, fulfilling 'blessing' part of call.
Starts with angels in Sodom. Ends with destruction and Moab/Ammon origins. Devices: Resolves Lot subplot; contrasts Lot's moral decay with Abraham's righteousness.
Starts with Abraham in Gerar. Ends with Abimelech restoring Sarah. Devices: Wife-sister repetition; God intervenes in dream to protect promise.
Starts with Isaac's birth. Ends with Sarah's laughter resolution. Devices: Son promise fulfilled after 25 years; Yitzhak (laughter) wordplay completed.
Starts with Sarah's demand. Ends with God protecting Hagar/Ishmael. Devices: Resolves heir tension with pathos; clarifies promise line (Isaac) while showing God's care for Ishmael.
Starts with 'Abraham!' call. Ends with full command. Devices: Repetitive, agonizing 'your son, your only son, whom you love—Isaac' builds pathos.
Starts with immediate obedience. Ends with first 'walked on together.' Devices: Narrative sparsity (3-day silence builds tension); repetition.
Starts with Isaac's question. Ends with Abraham's answer and second 'walked on together.' Devices: Central dialogue of chiasm; dramatic irony; wordplay yir'eh→YHWH-Yireh.
Starts with binding. Ends with place naming. Devices: Climax (v.10) broken by divine call; 'Here I am' inclusio (v.1, 11); etiology/wordplay YHWH-Yireh.
Starts with angel's second call. Ends with Beersheba return, closing pericope. Devices: Promise restated as unconditional oath because Abraham passed test.
Starts with Sarah's death. Ends with Machpelah purchase. Devices: First legal land acquisition, 'token' promise fulfillment; formal legal negotiation.
Starts with servant's charge. Ends with Isaac/Rebekah marriage. Devices: Longest Genesis chapter, showing lineage importance; divine providence (camel test).
Starts with other descendants. Ends with formal inclusio: 'after Abraham's death, God blessed his son Isaac,' passing torch. Devices: Completes entire cycle.

stories.story_title: The Jacob Cycle: Struggle and Transformation
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with Isaac toledot (25:19), immediately introducing struggling twins, cycle's inciting incident. Ends with Bethel return (35:1-15) and Israel renaming (35:10), resolving descent; closes with Isaac's death (35:29), passing authority. Chapter 36 clears Esau. Large chiasm: A: Land/conflict Esau (25-27)→B: Bethel vision/departure (28)→C: Center: Haran/Laban conflict (29-31)→B': Peniel vision/return (32)→A': Land/Esau reconciliation (33-35). Theme of struggle in Jacob's name: struggles with Esau (birthright), Isaac (blessing), Laban (wives/wages), God (32), resulting in Israel ('struggles with God'). Irony: deceiver (Jacob/goatskins) is deceived (Laban/Leah).

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with toledot and Rebekah's barrenness. Ends with birth and naming of conflicting characters. Devices: Divine oracle ('two nations...one stronger') sets up cycle's conflict.
Starts with Jacob cooking. Ends with Esau despising birthright. Devices: Characterization (Esau impulsive, Jacob cunning).
Starts with famine. Ends with Esau's foreign wives. Devices: Wife-sister repetition from Abraham (Gen 12, 20), showing family failing pattern.
Starts with Isaac's command to Esau. Ends with Jacob's successful deception. Devices: High drama, irony (Jacob lives name), sensory detail (touch, smell, taste).
Starts with Esau's reaction. Ends with Jacob sent by both parents (Rebekah, Isaac). Devices: Initiates Frame A of chiasm.
Starts with Jacob alone at Bethel. Ends with vow. Devices: Chiastic hinge (B); God unilaterally gives Abrahamic promise to Jacob; etiology (Bethel, House of God).
Starts with Jacob meeting Rachel. Ends with bridal switch and 7-year agreement. Devices: Center of measure-for-measure irony: deceiver deceived.

scenes.scene_name: The Birth of Sons (Womb War) (Frame C)
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Leah's first son. Ends with Joseph's birth. Devices: Structured by Leah-Rachel conflict; each son's naming reflects rivalry wordplay.
Starts with leave request. Ends with Jacob wealthy. Devices: Deceiver at best, using folk-magic (speckled goats) covering selective breeding, turning Laban's deception back.
Starts with sons' jealousy. Ends with Galeed covenant. Devices: Mirrors Jacob's Esau flight; conflict resolved through covenant.
Starts with Mahanaim angel vision. Ends with Jacob alone at Jabbok. Devices: Narrative suspense ('greatly afraid and distressed').
Starts with Jacob alone. Ends with antagonist striking hip. Devices: Mystery (man unidentified); wordplay Ya'aqov/Yabboq/'bq wrestling.
Starts with man asking release. Ends with man blessing Jacob. Devices: Dialogue; renaming (Jacob→Israel) is theological climax signifying transformation.
Starts with Peniel naming. Ends with sinew law explanation. Devices: Wordplay Peniel (Face of God); symbolism (limp signifies breaking and dependence).
Starts with Jacob preparing for Esau. Ends with peaceful separation. Devices: Resolves Ch 27 conflict; allusion (Jacob having seen 'face of God' says 'your face like God's' to Esau).
Starts with Dinah 'going out.' Ends with brothers' violent revenge and Jacob's condemnation. Devices: Brutal story contrasts reconciliation (Ch 33) with Cain-like violence; family still flawed.

scenes.scene_name: Jacob's Return to Bethel (Frame A' Resolution)
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with God's return command. Ends with Isaac's death, closing toledot and story. Devices: Final chiasm act; Jacob purges idols; God formally renames Israel (35:10), completing transformation.

stories.story_title: The Joseph Novella: Providence and Reconciliation
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with Jacob toledot (37:1), immediately introducing core conflict: Joseph's dreams and brothers' envy→slavery. Ends with Joseph's death, final Genesis verse, closing patriarchal age, setting Exodus stage. Reversal theme: Joseph pit→slavery→prison→power; brothers aggressors→supplicants; famine threat→provision. Motifs: Clothing (coat 37→garment 39→robes 41→sets 45); Dreams (Joseph 37→cupbearer/baker 40→Pharaoh 41). Providence vs. sin tension: 'you sold me...God sent me.' Deliberate interruption (38): Judah-Tamar parallels Joseph's morality, develops Judah who steps up in 44.

scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Joseph introduction as 'old age son.' Ends with second dream intensifying hatred. Inciting incident. Devices: Dreams as central plot driver.
Starts with Joseph seeking brothers. Ends with pit throwing. Devices: Dialogue reveals malice ('dreamer'); irony: Reuben's rescue plan sets up failure.
Starts with Judah's idea ('sell him'). Ends with transaction complete. Devices: Two sale versions (Ishmaelites/Midianites) highlight source-blending.
Starts with bloody coat deception. Ends with Jacob's grief ('go to Sheol'). Devices: Coat as deception tool; irony (Jacob deceived by goat as he deceived father—measure-for-measure).

Self-contained novella. Starts with Judah leaving. Ends with 'more righteous than I.' Devices: Deliberate thematic interruption paralleling Joseph (garment recognition); contrasts Judah's sin with Joseph's faithfulness (Ch 39); Perez→David ancestor.
Starts with Joseph's success. Ends with imprisonment after fleeing. Devices: Garment again falsely used; contrasts Joseph's faithfulness with Judah's failure.
Starts with Joseph in charge. Ends with cupbearer's release and forgetting. Devices: Dreams return; creates suspense and false resolution (out of pit, not prison).
Starts with Pharaoh's two dreams. Ends with promotion to second-in-command. Devices: Great reversal; Ch 37 dreams now fulfilled; clothing motif (robes signify status).
Starts with administration. Ends with famine beginning. Devices: Son-naming wordplay (Manasseh=forget; Ephraim=fruitful) shows personal resolution before brothers reappear.
Starts with Jacob sending sons. Ends with return minus Simeon. Devices: Dramatic irony (reader knows Joseph; brothers don't); Ch 37 dreams explicitly fulfilled ('bowed'); Joseph tests as spies.
Starts with Jacob's reluctance. Ends with Judah guaranteeing Benjamin. Devices: Character development: Judah who sold Joseph now guarantees brother's safety.
Starts with brothers' terror (money fear). Ends with Joseph honoring Benjamin. Devices: Dramatic irony continues; Joseph weeps privately, showing internal conflict.

Starts with cup-planting command. Ends with Judah's climactic self-offer as slave for Benjamin. Devices: Final test paralleling original sin (beloved Rachel son loss); Judah offers life for brother—Cain reversal.
Starts with room clearing. Ends with brothers dismayed. Devices: Catharsis (wept aloud); repetition ('I am Joseph!'); resolves dramatic irony.
Starts with 'Come close...' Ends with 'God sent me...to preserve life.' Devices: Retrospective narrative; antithesis 'you sold me' vs. 'God sent me' (3x)—novella's theme.
Starts with 'Hurry...go up...' Ends with kissing/reconciliation. Devices: Moves from speech to action, sealing forgiveness.
Starts with Pharaoh's news. Ends with departure with carts/provisions. Devices: Logistical resolution; Pharaoh's gladness validates Joseph's plan.
Starts with Beersheba sacrifice. Ends with Goshen arrival. Devices: God's vision sanctioning move; resolves patriarchal 'going down' fear.
Starts with money failure. Ends with Egypt (except priests) enslaved to Pharaoh. Devices: Explains political-economic backdrop for Exodus.
Starts with Jacob near death. Ends with Joseph swearing Canaan burial. Devices: Reaffirms land promise from Abraham cycle.
Starts with blessing Joseph's sons. Ends with crossed-hands blessing. Devices: Thematic repetition: younger (Ephraim) blessed over elder (Manasseh), mirroring Jacob's story; God's election theme.
Starts with gathering all sons. Ends with final charge. Devices: Poetic oracles collection; Judah blessing (49:8-12) forecasts kingship, passes scepter—resolves his character arc (Ch 37-38).

Starts with Jacob's death. Ends with Joseph's final statement: 'You intended harm, God intended good.' Devices: Long formal funeral procession to Canaan reinforces land promise; Joseph's last act is faith in promise (bones to promised land); coffin in Egypt hooks to Exodus. Resolves entire book's agency/providence tension.
